awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a Drop Tower Impact Test Capability at Penn State Erie, The Behrend College
awd_abstract_narration:
This Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) award supports the acquisition of a drop tower impact test instrument at Penn State Erie, The Behrend College.  Many component and structural failures are due to sudden catastrophic fractures that often occur without warning.  The discipline that addresses these effects is fracture mechanics.  If mechanical loading reach critical levels, catastrophic failure may occur.  Understanding the conditions that may lead to fracture requires test facilities that can vary parameters such as temperature, component shape, and impact velocity.  Sudden fracture events occur over very small timeframes, like milliseconds or microseconds.  This requires high speed camera capability that can capture these events for detailed study.  The drop tower impact test instrument has these features and complements a set of other test techniques at Penn State Erie.  A wide range of materials, including metals, polymers and composites, can be understood in terms of their fracture behavior and this will enable closer collaboration with industry partners who must design failure resistant parts and structures.  This instrument will also enable instruction on fracture and impact in engineering courses at the college level, while also supporting student centered undergraduate research, industrial workforce development in plastics engineering, and a summer outreach program with middle school girls.

The primary objective of the research program to be centered on this acquisition is to explore the rate-dependence of the ductile/brittle fracture transition for both longstanding material formulations and new chemistries and microstructure distributions. The scope also includes use of this technique to induce controlled rapid deformation of oriented polymer samples to better understand strain-induced crystallization in thermoplastics, building on established research at Penn State Erie. Several fracture modeling analysis theories have been planned including essential work of fracture, crack opening displacement, crack tip opening displacement, virtual crack closure, and J-integral.  All of these have limitations, often imposed by the fundamental material characteristics.  In combination with numerical analysis techniques, the data provided by the drop tower impact test instrument capability will allow these modeling approaches to be evaluated, evolved and optimized for a broad range of polymeric, metallic and composite materials.  The fundamental goal is to achieve reliable fracture models for materials of variable morphologies and architectures based on accurate characterization of material deformation and crack propagation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Penn State Erie, The Behrend College

por.por_cntn:
The Instron Drop Tower Impact tester and associated High Speed Video Camera allows the impact properties of engineering materials to be determined in a way that reveals the mechanisms occurring during the failure process.  When common materials are subjected to impact, they may break in a manner that is determined by a wide range of factors, like chemical and elemental composition, arrangement of constituent elements in three-dimensional space and design of the structure or the component they comprise.  Materials may behave completely differently when subjected to steady or statics loads and sudden impacts.  It is not possible to complete reliable design of products or structures without knowledge of how constituent materials fail if subjected to impact.  A common example, of which many in the public is aware, is the crash behavior of automobiles.  Safer cars are made possible through a good understanding of fracture or ‘crumpling’ properties.  The Drop Tower Impact system acquired by Penn State, Erie in 2023 has been used in the educational, research and outreach missions of the University.  It has been integrated into instruction in several courses taught at the college, addressing such topics as plastic and polymer characterization, mechanical properties of plastics, failure analysis and material optimization.  It has also greatly enhanced the Senior Design experience, in which students are challenged to solve real world problems for industrial collaborators and sponsors.  Penn State Erie has an extensive outreach initiative, where students in elementary, middle and high schools are provided opportunities to explore STEM topics, and the instrument has garnered a very positive reaction from visiting students, likely increasing enrollment in engineering and technology courses.  Finally, the test system has generated great interest in the industrial research community and funded projects are expected to begin in the short term.  Companies such as Clarience- Truck Lite and Kyocera have indicated interest and Penn State’s Applied Research Laboratory anticipates using the capability in research and development activities funded by the Department of Defense.          


Last Modified: 09/29/2024
Modified by: Gregory P Dillon

por.por_txt_cntn:
The Instron Drop Tower Impact tester andassociated High Speed Video Camera allows the impact properties of engineering materials to be determined in a way that reveals the mechanisms occurring during the failure process. When common materials are subjected to impact, they may break in a manner that is determined by a wide range of factors, like chemical and elemental composition, arrangement of constituent elements in three-dimensional space and design of the structure or the component they comprise. Materials may behave completely differently when subjected to steady or statics loads and sudden impacts. It is not possible to complete reliable design of products or structures without knowledge of how constituent materials fail if subjected to impact. A common example, of which many in the public is aware, is the crash behavior of automobiles. Safer cars are made possible through a good understanding of fracture or crumpling properties. The Drop Tower Impact system acquired by Penn State, Erie in 2023 has been used in the educational, research and outreach missions of the University. It has been integrated into instruction in several courses taught at the college, addressing such topics as plastic and polymer characterization, mechanical properties of plastics, failure analysis and material optimization. It has also greatly enhanced the Senior Design experience, in which students are challenged to solve real world problems for industrial collaborators and sponsors. Penn State Erie has an extensive outreach initiative, where students in elementary, middle and high schools are provided opportunities to explore STEM topics, and the instrument has garnered a very positive reaction from visiting students, likely increasing enrollment in engineering and technology courses. Finally, the test system has generated great interest in the industrial research community and funded projects are expected to begin in the short term. Companies such as Clarience- Truck Lite and Kyocera have indicated interest and Penn States Applied Research Laboratory anticipates using the capability in research and development activities funded by the Department of Defense. 					Last Modified: 09/29/2024

					Submitted by: GregoryPDillon
